posts.name: couvillion
posts.cooked:
We have built a EveryBot we have a some confusing behavior. The arm is acting like it has a very high static friction, however the arm moves freely.

Often the arm won‚Äôt move until some extra energy is put in to either by nudging the arm or jostling the robot forward and backwards, it will then ‚Äúcatch‚Äù and move with vigor.

I have also observed that the dashboard reports a speed set command value 1 or -1, and the light on the sparkmax also is forward or backwards, the current for the motor however will read zero.

Any one have any ideals on how to trouble shoot this?

posts.name: Emile Hamwey
posts.cooked: Check to see if you have a damaged NEO. We have seen on one or two occasions that a NEO will not provide power when its shaft is in a certain position, likely due to a singular burnt winding internally that can‚Äôt be commutated in certain positions.

posts.name: Mr.R^2
posts.cooked:
Also check to see if one of the cables on the neo is unplugged. That is expected behavior if there are only two of the three power cables attached. The other thing may be that the arm is getting hung up on the inner limit. One other thing to check is if you are using the max 90 gearbox if it has the out of tolerance issue or if it is assembled too tight. We had the latter issue happen with one of ours.

Edit: I somehow missed the spark max issues. That may count out the mechanical issues, but may still point to the cable being unplugged.

posts.name: couvillion
posts.cooked: How would you judge too tight? I vaguely recall wondering if it was moving as freely as it should, but I had no feel for what it ought to be like.

posts.name: Mr.R^2
posts.cooked:
Rev posted a video. I cannot find it now, but I can look tomorrow. The cliff notes version was, it should feel like a fidget spinner in your hands. We have two, one did, and the other was stuck in places. We originally thought it was one of the bad ones, but our mechanical mentor took it home and rebuilt it, and it is smooth as silk. I think we either overtightened it or put a bearing in backwards.

Edit: Here is the video from the other thread.

REV Robotics - 2022/23 Product Releases & Updates General Forum

posts.name: Brandon Liatys
posts.cooked: This sounds like it could be a bad motor or motor wiring to me. If one of the 3 neo wires aren‚Äôt properly connected it results in similar behavior to this if I remember correctly. This break in connection could be either in your wiring or in a burnt winding as someone said previously. I‚Äôve had this issue happen with a poorly done anderson connector not making contact even though it appeared to be connected.

posts.name: couvillion
posts.cooked:
The winner is bad PowerPole connection between the SparkMax and the NEO. Actually had visible melting in the housing for the white wiring.

I should mention also the current draw on the motor went way down, even when the motor seemed to be moving normally. If you have high current draw on a brushless motor check the connector.
